title: Reverse Words in a String II
content:
Given a character array s, reverse the order of the words.

A word is defined as a sequence of non-space characters. The words in s will be separated by a single space.

Your code must solve the problem in-place, i.e. without allocating extra space.

 

Example 1:

Input: s = ["t","h","e"," ","s","k","y"," ","i","s"," ","b","l","u","e"]
Output: ["b","l","u","e"," ","i","s"," ","s","k","y"," ","t","h","e"]

Example 2:

Input: s = ["a"]
Output: ["a"]

 

Constraints:

  • 1 <= s.length <= 105
  • s[i] is an English letter (uppercase or lowercase), digit, or space ' '.
  • There is at least one word in s.
  • s does not contain leading or trailing spaces.
  • All the words in s are guaranteed to be separated by a single space.
solution:
Solution Article

Approach 1: Reverse the Whole String and Then Reverse Each Word

To have this problem in Amazon interview is a good situation since the input is a mutable structure and hence one could aim O(1) space solution without any technical difficulties.

The idea is simple: reverse the whole string and then reverse each word.

Algorithm

Let's first implement two functions:

  • reverse(l: list, left: int, right: int), which reverses array characters between left and right pointers. Java users can implement this helper function directly since character arrays are mutable.

  • reverse_each_word(l: list), which uses two pointers to mark the boundaries of each word and the previous function to reverse it.

Now reverseWords(s: List[str]) implementation is straightforward:

  • Reverse the whole string: reverse(s, 0, len(s) - 1).

  • Reverse each word: reverse_each_word(s).

Implementation

class Solution {

    // Summary: Reverse entire string. Then reverse each word within the string.
    public void reverseWords(char[] s) {
        int n = s.length;

        // Reverse the entire array
        reverse(s, 0, n - 1);

        // 'start' points to the beginning of the current word
        // 'end' points to the position just after the current word
        int start = 0;
        int end = 0;

        while (start < n) {

            // Move 'end' to the position just after the current word
            while (end < n && s[end] != ' ') {
                end++;
            }

            // Reverse characters in the range [start, end - 1]
            reverse(s, start, end - 1);

            // Move 'start' and 'end' to the beginning of the next word
            end++;
            start = end;
        }
    }

    // Helper function to reverse characters between left and right indices
    private void reverse(char[] s, int left, int right) {
        while (left < right) {
            char temp = s[left];
            s[left] = s[right];
            s[right] = temp;
            left++;
            right--;
        }
    }
}

Complexity Analysis

  • Time complexity: O(N), it's two passes along the string.

  • Space complexity: O(1), it's a constant space solution.
